turns.speaker: RICKY
turns.text: Who's gonna outfit us?

turns.speaker: RUIZ
turns.text: Outfit? What's he talking about?

turns.speaker: RICKY
turns.text: The Red Dragon.

turns.speaker: RUIZ
turns.text: Shut it, man. Shut it. Tom is a square. He don't but dabble in shit. Maxie had me hook up a loan-back with him, through an Austrian passbook account.

turns.speaker: RICKY
turns.text: So, we're talking money laundering...

turns.speaker: RUIZ
turns.text: Will you tell Peter Jennings to shut up and fucking listen. The shit's as routine as you get. I coulda turned it over offshore in a week, but Maxie likes to do it all his way. Safe. I coulda dropped the bag alone. It's only two hundred G's. But he sent you all. So I can either send you home and tell Maxie, or we can flush the toilet one more time and hope it all goes down.

turns.speaker: RICKY
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: RUIZ
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: RICKY
turns.text: When all this is over and we're not working for Maxie, I'd love to run into you on the street.  Why aren't you coming?

turns.speaker: RUIZ
turns.text: That's none of your fucking business.

turns.speaker: WELSHMAN
turns.text: And here I thought you flew in some out of town muscle. How's it going, men?

turns.speaker: RICKY
turns.text: So, you must be the Red Dragon.

turns.speaker: WELSHMAN
turns.text: Well, that's news to me. The name's Tom.

turns.speaker: RICKY
turns.text: Mmmm-hmm. Where's the, uh, 'Dragon's lair?' Where do you live?

turns.speaker: WELSHMAN
turns.text: Edinburgh.

turns.speaker: RICKY
turns.text: And where might that be?

turns.speaker: WELSHMAN
turns.text: Scotland.

turns.speaker: RICKY
turns.text: Well, word on the street is you're Welsh.

turns.speaker: WELSHMAN
turns.text: I am.

turns.speaker: RICKY
turns.text: A rose by any other name would --

turns.speaker: RICKY
turns.text: Dip?

turns.speaker: WELSHMAN
turns.text: Yeah. This shit's fucking brilliant. I just fucking love the fact that you have kids driving around in pickup trucks with a mouthful of this shit, speeding their brains out. I gotta bring a case of it home to my mates. It's illegal back home, you know.

turns.speaker: RICKY
turns.text: I'll get it.

turns.speaker: WELSHMAN
turns.text: Who's up for a night on the town.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: Sit down. We ain't fixing to eat you. You look brand new in town. Pretty handy with a bottle.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: He had it coming.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: What they call you?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Red, and I ain't no punk.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: You better not be. Cause if a cat toe you down in this town, you better stand up or make tracks.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: I'm working trains. Selling.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: Bet you like that shit.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Keeps me out of the army.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: When they want your ass, won't nothing keep you out.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Not this boy... I ain't fighting their war. I got my own. Right chere. Heard tell you're a good man to know.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: Heard where?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Where I come from. Boston.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: Sombitch and I ain't never been to Beantown.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Man's rep travels.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: How 'bout that?

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: You ain't bullshitting me, is you, boy?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: My papa taught me one thing: don't never bullshit a West Indian bullshit artist.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: Is your papa West Indian?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: No, my mama. She's from Grenada.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: I like you, country.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Where can I get a hold of you?

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: YOU can't. I'll get a hold of you.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Lemme write it down for you.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: Don't never write nothing down. File it up here, like I do.  'Cause if they can't find no paper they ain't got no proof. Ya dig?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: Did you just now con me?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: 'Cause I want in. And it don't take a lot to know you there, daddy.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: I like your heart and I like your style. You might just do, Little. Lessen you got to git back to that train job.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: I done told the man what he could do with his train.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: When?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Just now.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: You looking good, Little. Real clean. Clean as the Board of Health. But you missing something.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: Frisk me, baby. Give me a real pat down.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: How's it feel?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Solid, daddy.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: Okay, baby. Now you outfitted. You ready to tackle the street?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Let 'em come. I'm ready.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: I told you less paper, less trouble.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: I'm working on it.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: I keep all my numbers in my head. I've never written any down.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: It hit?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Nnnnnnn!

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: Ain't nuthin' in the world to give you that real deep cool. Like girl. You there?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: I'm there, daddy. Wheww. I'm cool enough to kill.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: Bet you are.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: Sometimes you got a big ugly mouth.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Yeah, and I'm putting my money where my ugly mouth is. I'm putting you back in the numbers right now.  Baby, what's today?

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: I'll take your goddam bet.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Daddy, where's my money?

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: What you talking?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: You owe me six big ones.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: 1, 2, 8 hit, didn't it?

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: You din't have no 1, 2, 8.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Was you that high? Old man, I threw the slats at you. I said to combinate me.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: You never had it.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: The bitch was there.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: Shit, what else she gonna say?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Then skip it, man. But you slipping, baby. You done slipped.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Oh, sit down, man. What you tasting? I'm buying.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: I ain't drinking hot piss with you. Come on, Sam.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: You're a damn liar.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: You _took_ me, you bastard, and now I'm taking you.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: It's me or you, ain't it, Pops?

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: You know it.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: I'll give you back the 600.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: I don't want your money.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: I'm wearing, Archie.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: There's two guns on you.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: And every cat's watching, ain't they? It's a toe-down.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: That's what it is. Walk on out.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Let Billie finish.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: Now.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Take it easy, baby.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: That really you, Red?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: You saved my life, Archie. Running me out of Harlem. When I think how close we came to gunning each other down, I have to thank Allah.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: I wasn't gonna shoot you, baby. It was just my rep, that's all. And don't shit me now, but did you have that number? Tell me.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: I don't know. It doesn't matter. The thing is we got to get you back on your feet.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: Yeah. I got a couple a new angles ain't been figured yet. All I need's a stake and a  chance --

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Can you use a few bucks? I ain't got much, but --

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: No, man, I'm doing okay. Thanks.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Take it easy. Lay down and don't think about it.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: You could of been something, Archie, but the devil got to you.

turns.speaker: SAMMY
turns.text: Man live by his rep.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: That's a fact. What you do, boy?

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: Yeah, got to do something about you.

turns.speaker: SAMMY
turns.text: You putting a hurtin' on my vision.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: The dirty yellow rat bastard.

turns.speaker: SAMMY
turns.text: Don't push it. You way ahead. You back on top. That boy loves you, man.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: What you say?

turns.speaker: SAMMY
turns.text: He gave it to you, Archie. He did.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Who the hell are you?

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: Put it in a cup of water. It's nutmeg.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Man, what do you want?

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: You need something. It's not a reefer, but it'll help some.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Man, get outa my face. I ain't nobody's punk.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: If you ain't trying to punk me, what's your hype?

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: I can show you how to get out of prison. And it's no hype.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Talk, daddy, I'm listening. Hey that ain't bad. You got some more?

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: That's the last stuff you'll ever get from me.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: What did you give it to me for then?

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: 'Cause you needed it. 'Cause you couldn't hear me without it.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: You ain't lying.

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: When you go busting your fists against a stone wall, you're not using your brains. Cause that's what the white man wants you to do. Look at you.

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: Putting all that poison in your hair.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Man, you been locked up too long, everybody conks. All the cats.

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: Why? Why does everybody conk?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Cause I don't want to walk around with my head all nappy, looking like --

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: Like what? Looking like me? Like a nigger?! Why don't you want to look like what you are? What makes you ashamed of being black?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: I ain't said I'm ashamed.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Leggo. I got to wash it out.

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: Let it burn. Maybe you'll hear me then.

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: Sure, burn yourself, pain yourself, put all that poison into your hair, into your body -- trying to be white.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Man, I don't want to hear all that.

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: I thought you was smart. But you just another one of them cats strutting down the avenue in your clown suit with all that mess on you. Like a monkey. And the white man sees you and he laughs. He laughs because he knows you ain't white.

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: The question is, who are you? You are in the darkness, but it's not your fault. Elijah Muhammad can bring you into the light.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Elijah who?

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: Elijah Muhammad can get you out of prison. Out of the prison of your mind. Maybe all you want is another fix. I thought you were smart.

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: What you sniffing around for? I told you I gave you your last fix.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: I ain't never seen a cat like you. Ain't you scared talking like that in front of an ofay?

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: What's he gonna do to me he ain't already done?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: You the only cat don't come on with that "Whatcha know, daddy" jive; and you don't cuss none.

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: I respect myself. A man cuss because he hasn't got the words to say what's on his mind.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Tell you this: you ain't no fool.

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: Don't con me. Don't try...

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Okay, okay.

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: Don't con me.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: What do you do with your time?

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: I read. I study. Because the first thing a black man has to do is respect himself. Respect his body and his mind. Quit taking the white man's poison into your body: his cigarettes, his dope, his liquor, his white woman, his pork.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: That's what Mama used to say.

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: Your mama had sense because the pig is a filthy beast: part rat, part cat, and the rest is dog.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Come on, daddy, pull my coat. What happens if you give all that up? You get sick or somethin'? I pulled a hustle once and got out of the draft.

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: I'm telling you God's words, not no hustle. I'm talking the words of Elijah, the black man's God. I'm telling you, boy, that God is black.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: What? Everybody knows God is White.

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: But everything the white man taught you, you learned. He told you you were a black heathen and you believed him. He told you how he took you out of darkness and brought you to the light. And you believed him. He taught you to worship a blond, blue-eyed God with white skin -- and you believed him. He told you black was a curse, you believed him. Did you ever look up the word black in the dictionary?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: What for?

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: Did you ever study anything wasn't part of some con?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: What the hell for, man?

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: Go on, fool; the marble shooters are waiting for you.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Okay, okay. Show me, man.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: I can't make out that shit.

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: Soiled with dirt, foul; sullen, hostile, forbidding -- as a black day. Foully or outrageously wicked, as black cruelty. Indicating disgrace, dishonor or culpability.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: That's bullshit. That's a white man's book. Ain't all these white man's books?

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: They sure ain't no black man's books in here.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Then what you telling me to study in them for?

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: You got to learn everything the white man says and use it against him. The truth is laying there if you smart and read behind their words. It's buried there. You got to dig it out.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Man, how'm I gonna know the ones worth looking at?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Man, I'm studying in the man's book. I don't dig half the words.

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: Look 'em up and and out what they mean.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Where am I gonna start?

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: Start at the beginning. Page one, the first one. Here --

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Aardvark, noun. An earth pig; an ant- eating African mammal. Man, that sounds like the dozens.

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: Read it and keep on reading.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Ole Pete ain't much in the head, but he can lay in there with the wood.

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: Lemme tell you about history: black history. You listening?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: You pitch, baby; I'll ketch.

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: The first men on earth were black. They ruled and there was not one white face anywhere. But they teach us that we lived in caves and swung from trees. Black men were never like that.

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: Sure, white man throw us a bone and that's supposed to make us forget 400 years.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: A black man playing big league ball is something.

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: I told you to go behind the words and dig out the truth. They let us sing and dance and smile -- and now they let one black man in the majors. That don't cancel out the greatest crime in history. When that blue- eyed devil locked us in chains -- 100,000,000 of us -- broke up our families, tortured us, cut us off from our language, our religion, our history.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Little.

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: No. That's the name of the slave- master who owned your family. You don't even know who you are. You're nothing. Less than nothing. A zero. Who are you?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: I'm not Malcolm Little and I'm not Satan.

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: Who are you?

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: Allah has sent us a prophet, a black man named Elijah Muhammad. For if God is black, Malcolm --

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Then the devil is white.

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: I knew you'd hear me. The white man is the devil. All white men are devils.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: I sure met some.

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: No. Elijah Muhammad does not say "that white man is a devil." He teaches us that the white man is the devil. All white men.

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: The body is a holy repository.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: I will not touch the white man's poison: his drugs, his liquor, his carrion, his women.

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: A Muslim must be strikingly upright. Outstanding. So those in the darkness can see the power of the light.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: I will do it.

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: But the key to Islam is submission. That is why twice daily we turn to Mecca, to the Holy of Holies, to pray. We bend our knees in submission.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: I can't.

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: For evil to bend its knee, admit its guilt, implore His forgiveness, is the hardest thing on earth --

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: I want to, Bembry, but I can't.

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: -- the hardest and the greatest.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: I can't.

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: For evil to bend its knee, admit its guilt, implore His forgiveness, is the hardest thing on earth --

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: I want to, Bembry, but I can't.

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: -- the hardest and the greatest.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: I don't know what to say to Allah.

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: Have you ever bent your knees, Malcolm?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Yeah. When I was picking a lock to rob somebody's house.

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: Tell Him that.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: I don't know how.

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: You can grovel and crawl for sin, but not to save your soul. Pick the lock, Malcolm; pick it.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: I want to. God knows I want to.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Brother Bembry, can we fix it so our loudspeaker is heard on the street?

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: I'm sure we can. This is a new sister, Sister Betty.

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: Now about our coming up in the world a little. You're not naive. You're a man of the world. The Movement's grown; we've grown with it. You know folks. They want their leaders to be prosperous. One hand washes the other.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: "I'm telling you God's words, not to hustle."

turns.speaker: BEMBRY
turns.text: You want a new car? You want a new house? Is that it? It's the money, right?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: What can I do for you?

turns.speaker: BENJAMIN
turns.text: Mr. X, I was out there tonight. I saw what you did. I want to be a Muslim. I ain't never seen a Negro stand up to the police like that.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Do you?

turns.speaker: BENJAMIN
turns.text: Not exactly, but I want to be one, like you.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: I admire your enthusiasm but you should never join any organization without first checking it out thoroughly.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: We need more young warriors like yourself, stick around and we shall see if your heart is true.

turns.speaker: BENJAMIN
turns.text: Mr. X, I won't make you out a liar.

turns.speaker: BENJAMIN
turns.text: I'll have it tomorrow.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Brother Benjamin, do not rush, it has to be exact.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: You are now Benjamin 2X.

turns.speaker: BENJAMIN 2X
turns.text: All praises are due to Allah. Thank you, Brother Minister.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Come, sit with us.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Is the program ready?

turns.speaker: BENJAMIN 2X
turns.text: No, Brother Minister.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Why not? You've had ample time, you and the sister.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Folks are sitting out there today, not next week, expecting to hear our program.

turns.speaker: BENJAMIN 2X
turns.text: Next week, Brother Minister.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Has the Reverend called? Is he going to show?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Make it plain.

turns.speaker: BENJAMIN 2X
turns.text: And now, without further remarks, I present to you one who is willing to put himself on the line for you --

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: She ate.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Sure I'll speak to your class. But I'm a hard man on women. You want to know why?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: If you want to tell me.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Women talk too much. To tell a woman not to talk is like telling Jesse James not to carry a gun or a hen not to cackle. And Samson, the strongest man that ever lived, was destroyed by the woman who slept in his arms.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Shall I tell my sisters that we oppose marriage?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: What points?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: That you haven't time for either marriage or eating --

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Considering today's standards of animal raising and curing meats, I don't fully understand the restriction on pork.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Let me explain. No. I'll do better than that. I'll show it to you. Scientifically. But it's demonstration purely in the interest of science, you understand?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: I see your point.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: So it is not a matter of the breeding conditions or preparation of the meat. The meat itself is foul.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Could we sit down someplace?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: I'm sorry. I've had you on your feet for hours.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: You've been on your feet for days. And didn't even finish your salad.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: That's something I haven't done in fifteen years.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Sat down with a pretty girl and had an ice cream soda.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: How do you like it?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Delicious.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Let's talk about you for a change.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: There's nothing to talk about.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Oh, yes, there is. I know a lot about you. Brother Bembry briefed me.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Oh? Purely scientific interest I'm sure.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: You're from Detroit, near where I come from. You majored in education at Tuskegee. You're studying nursing and having trouble with your family.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: I can handle it.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: They want you to quit the Muslims or they won't pay your tuition, isn't that it?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: You have enough worries of your own.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: No, good Sisters are rare. We need every one. Tell me something: how tall are you?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Why do you ask?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Just an idle question.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: If it's just idle, I won't answer it.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: But Brother Bembry says I'm tall enough for a tall man.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: How old are you, Betty?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: There's a few things you don't know about women, Brother Malcolm. They're possessive and vain.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Are you?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: And dogged when I set my mind to something.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: What have you set your mind to?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Being a good Muslim, a good nurse and a good wife.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: I'm in Detroit.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: At a gas station.  Will you marry me?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Did you hear what I said?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Yes I did. Did you hear my answer?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: I think so. Can you catch a plane?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Yes. Did you eat?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: I love you.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: It won't be easy.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Just hold me.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: It will be rough.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Hush your mouth.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: I'll be away a lot.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: You're with me even when you're away.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: I never told you, but when I first saw you on the podium, cleaning your glasses, I felt sorry for you. Nobody as young as you should be that serious. But I don't think that anymore.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: What do you think?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: The simplest thing in the world: I want to have a lot of babies with you. Dear Heart, I love you.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Why are you looking at me like that?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Because you're in trouble.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: How do you know?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: I don't want to bring my troubles home. You know that.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: I'm not made of glass.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: I just want to sit here and be still.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: We've never had a fight. Not a real one. But we're going to have one right now if you don't talk about it.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Talk about what?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: The talk is everywhere!

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: There's always talk, always been talk, and always will be talk. Don't they say how I'm trying to take over the Nation, how I'm getting rich off the Nation?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: We'll get to that, too, but this isn't just talk any more.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: "Los Angeles, UPI: Elijah Muhammad, 67-year-old leader of the Black Muslim Movement, today faced paternity suits from two former secretaries who charged he fathered their four children..."

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: There are always slanders, always lies. You're reading the devil's lies. Can't you see they're trying to bring us down, bring down the Messenger.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: "Both women, in their 20's, charged they had had intimacies with Elijah Muhammad since 1957..."

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: I was going to talk to Bembry about it tonight.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: To Bembry? Is Bembry your friend?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Woman, have you lost your mind? What's the matter with you?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: No, what's the matter with you? Wake up! Are you so dedicated that you have blinded yourself? Are you so committed you cannot face the truth? Bembry is the editor of the newspaper you established. Ask him why your name hasn't been in "Muhammad Speaks" in over a year? Ask him why you rate front page in every paper in the country, but not a single sentence in your own.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: I'm not interested in personal publicity. Our people know what I'm doing.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Do you know what Bembry is doing? You're so blind, everyone can see this but you!!!

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Bembry saved my Life. The Honorable Elijah Muhammad saved my life.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: A long time ago. You've repaid them many times over. Ask them why they have new cars and houses full of new furniture.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Is that what this is about? Material wealth?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: What do we have, Malcolm. A broken- down jalopy and the clothes on our backs. We don't even own our own home. What about our children? What about me? You don't even own life insurance.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: The Nation will provide for you and the children if anything happens to me.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Will they? Are you sure? Are you sure or are you blind?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Dear heart, you have to help me. I'm raising our kids practically by myself, while you're running all over the world. You don't know how many times the girls ask me when is daddy coming home?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: What do you want me to do? Our people need me.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: We need you too!

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: What do you want me to do?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Open your eyes, you can face death 24 hours a day; but the possibility of betrayal never enters your mind. If you won't do that for yourself do it for us.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Get some sleep.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: You have to sleep for three.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: I'm sorry. I haven't been the best husband or father.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Shhh!

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Families shouldn't be separated. I'll never make another long trip without you and the kids. We'll all be together.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Dear heart, I love you.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: We had the best organization that black people ever had and niggers ruined it.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Stop calling us. Leave us alone. Leave us alone. I'll kill you. I'll kill you.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Betty it's me. It's me.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Malcolm, they keep calling, threatening us. I'm going crazy, when is this going to stop?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Don't answer the phone. It's all right. It's all right. Nothing is gonna happen to anybody.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Dear heart, where are you?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: At the Hilton. The girls asleep?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: I just put them to bed. Can we come to the meeting tomorrow?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: I don't think that's such a good idea.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: I want to also, but until we are instructed by the Messenger to do so, we will just wait and pray.

turns.speaker: BROTHER EARL
turns.text: I'm tired of praying.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: That's enough, Brother Earl.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: I don't care about myself, my wife and four children were sleeping in their beds, they have nothing to do with this.

turns.speaker: BROTHER EARL
turns.text: Let's get out of this cold.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Brother Earl.

turns.speaker: BROTHER EARL
turns.text: Malcolm, where are you? We've been calling all over the city.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: I'm gonna try and get some work done tonight.

turns.speaker: BROTHER EARL
turns.text: Let some of us come down there.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: No, that won't be necessary. I'll be all right.

turns.speaker: BROTHER EARL
turns.text: I wish you'd listen to us. What about the meeting tomorrow? We need to frisk people.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: I don't want folks to be searched, it makes people uncomfortable. If I can't be safe among my own kind, where can I be? Allah will protect me.

turns.speaker: BROTHER EARL
turns.text: Reverend Chickenwing called last night and said he wouldn't be able to attend.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: So now we have no opening speaker? Why wasn't I informed last night?

turns.speaker: BROTHER EARL
turns.text: I called Sister Betty, she didn't tell you?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Since when do you start telling Sister Betty my business? Since when? She has nothing to do with this. You tell me, not her, not anybody else.

turns.speaker: BROTHER EARL
turns.text: I assumed...

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: What did I tell you about assuming?

turns.speaker: BROTHER EARL
turns.text: Brother Minister, what is wrong?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: The way I feel, I ought not to go out there today. In fact, I'm going to ease some of this tension by telling the black man not to fight himself -- that's all a part of the white man's big maneuver, to keep us fighting amongst ourselves, against each other. I'm not fighting anyone, that's not what we're here for.

turns.speaker: BROTHER EARL
turns.text: Let's cancel.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Is my family here yet?

turns.speaker: BROTHER EARL
turns.text: Down front as always.

turns.speaker: CHAPLAIN GILL
turns.text: Do you know what a friend you have in Jesus, son?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Preacher, take your tin Jesus and the Virgin Mary, both, and shove 'em.

turns.speaker: CHAPLAIN GILL
turns.text: Why don't you just ask your question?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: You've been talking about the disciples. What color were they?

turns.speaker: CHAPLAIN GILL
turns.text: I don't think we know for certain.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: They were Hebrew, weren't they?

turns.speaker: CHAPLAIN GILL
turns.text: That's right.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: As Jesus was. Jesus was also a Hebrew.

turns.speaker: CHAPLAIN GILL
turns.text: Just what is your question?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: What color were the original Hebrews?

turns.speaker: CHAPLAIN GILL
turns.text: I told you we don't know for certain.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Then we don't know that God was white.

turns.speaker: CHAPLAIN GILL
turns.text: Now just a moment, just a moment --

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: But we do know that the people of that region of Asia Minor, from the Tigris-Euphrates valley to the Mediterranean, are dark-skinned people. I've studied drawings and photographs and seen newsreels. I have never seen a native of that area who was not black.

turns.speaker: CHAPLAIN GILL
turns.text: Just what are you saying?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: I'm not saying anything, preacher. I'm proving to you that God is black.
